results.title: Dutch oven cooking
results.brief_description: Illustrates the basic principles of fire building and Dutch oven cooking for hikers and campers. Emphasizes the care and precision which must be exercised when sharpening and using axes and knives; demonstrates the correct methods for chopping wood. Describes, step by step, the procedure for making a batch of biscuits including the preparation of the Dutch oven for baking.

results.title: Dusty hearts
results.creator_credit: Pauline Chan, Mariel Beros and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Sax Elthan is a hapless musician, a refugee from the inner city. Rejected by his girlfriend, he travels to the outback to look for work. One burning Wednesday he finds himself beside a highway, waiting for a lift, contemplating his future. It arrives in the shape of a beat-up Volkswagon with a wardrobe tied to the roof. A black comedy about one man’s destiny starring Geoff Morrell (Blue Heelers, Changi). Also features Tina Bursill.

results.title: Dusty (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Dusty is a film that will captivate with its values of love, loyalty and the quest for freedom. Based on the classic Australian book by Frank Dalby Davison, this is the story of an ill-fated bond between an old man and his dog. Tom Lincoln, an ageing drover, buys Dusty in a hotel, unaware that the dog is part kelpie and part dingo. He trains Dusty into a champion sheep dog but becomes aware his dog has the killer in his blood. Finally he returns to the bush, set apart from the world by his love for his dog. Rated: G

results.title: Dustbins in the sky
results.creator_credit: London Television Service, Bob Thorpe and Mike Lockey
results.brief_description: Made for the television program “Perspective”, this documentary examined the growth of technology in the collection, transmission and dissemination of news, from early cinema newsreels to today’s satellite coverage.

results.title: Dust to dust (A)
results.brief_description: This documentary narrated by Kerry Dwyer reveals how the use by the local council of asbestos tailings from the mine at Baryulgil in New South Wales, which operated until 1977, has affected the health of the predominantly Aboriginal population. The dust was used to maintain roads and keep the earth dust down around the houses. The school itself was built on the tailings. The film records what happened historically at Baryugil and follows the people’s attempts to gain workers’ compensation from the Dust Diseases Board.

results.title: Dust to dust
results.brief_description: Tells the story of a small town in northern NSW and the effects of asbestos mining there. The people estimate that three-quarters of the workers have died or are sick from exposure to asbestos. In presenting their story the film raises issues regarding occupational health in general.
results.description: Tells the story of a small town in northern NSW and the effects of asbestos mining there. results.title: Dust [Widescreen] (A)
results.creator_credit: Special Broadcasting Service Corporation, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Autumn Films, Teresa-Jayne Hanlon and Ivan Sen
results.brief_description: 2 cars arrive at a desolate cotton property. One car carries two feuding white teenagers Amy (Nathalie Roy) and Mick (Tristan Bancks)- the other 2 aboriginal youths Leroy (Clayton Munro) and Vance (Wayne Munro) and an elderly aboriginal woman called Ruby (Peta Binge). Under the fast moving clouds a storm is brewing, and when racism reaches a head and the dust storm finally erupts, the 5 find themselves confined in a car where they can no longer flee the tragedy of the past. Nominated for three AFI awards, Ivan Sen’s final film received a special commendation at the Clermonth Ferrand Short Film Festival.

results.title: Dust
results.creator_credit: Film Consortium, A history Dreams, Ena Films, Fandango, Shadow Films, Chris Auty, Vesna Jovanoska, Domenico Procacci and Milcho Manchevski
results.brief_description: Modern day Manhattan and an intruder, Edge, rifles through the apartment of an elderly lady, Angela who gets the better of him and bails him up with her rifle. At gunpoint Edge is forced to listen to a story from Angela’s past - two American rival brothers Luke (the elder and a fiery sharp shooter) and Elijah (a Bible quoting preacher) who lived at the turn of the 19th century. When Elijah marries the prostitute that Luke has designs on, the latter flees to Macedonia and joins the local resistance fighters who are trying to rid their country of occupying Turkish forces. Elijah pursues his brother across the world and signs up with the opposing forces, the Turkish leaders, in order to extract revenge. In “Dust”, present and past stories run parallel, occasionally melding, enabling Manchevski to remark upon the elusive nature of history. At times graphically bloody with a very high body count, the elliptical structure of “Dust” may frustrate some viewers but the cinematography and Macedonian setting are beautiful to watch. “Dust” is the second film from Macedonian director, Milcho Manchevski (Before the rain). Cast includes Joseph Fiennes, David Wenham, Adrian Lester, Anne Brochet.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Consortium, A history Dreams, Ena Films, Fandango, Shadow Films, Chris Auty, Vesna Jovanoska, Domenico Procacci and Milcho Manchevski

results.title: Dusi and Jeno
results.brief_description:
‘Dusi and Jeno’ is compiled from footage shot by Jeno, a Budapest bank worker, between 1936 and 1966.

At the heart of this diary film is his wife Dusi, for although Jeno ventures out to capture street life, holiday vistas and public events in elegant images and thoughtfully constructed sequences, he always returns to her side; Dusi and her beloved dog in a series of tender domestic tableau. He films them at breakfast, in the garden, in the sitting room - often elegantly framed by windows and doors. We see them glimpsed in silhouette on a train journey, or placed in a beautifully composed landscape. Dusi chats to him as he films; this is the record of a twenty year conversation, much of it we gather about their ever present dog.

Even the second world war is referenced by the domestic, with Jeno returning to film the site of their bomb-destroyed home from exactly the same place he had shot it basking in sunlight years before.

Dusi’s hair turns grey over the years, three dogs take their turn at her side. After her death Jeno remarries; the rhythm of images shifts, the love poem has ended.
